solution:
Since $18 - 14 = 4$, the common difference in the first column of squares is 4, so the number above 14 is $14 - 4 = 10$, and the number above 10 is $10 - 4 = 6$.  This is also the fourth number in the row, so the common difference in the row is $(6 - 21)/3 = -5$.

Then the seventh (and last) number in the row is $21 - 5 \cdot 6 = -9$.  In the second column, the common difference is $[(-17) - (-9)]/4 = -2$, so $N = -9 - (-2) = \boxed{-7}$.

Since the numbers in the second column form an arithmetic sequence with 14 and 18, the common difference is 18 − 14 = 4. Also, since the numbers in the row form an arithmetic sequence, the common difference is $N-21$, while the numbers in the third column form an arithmetic sequence, the common difference is −17 − (−3) = −14.
The numbers in the second column form an arithmetic sequence with common difference 4, so the number in the second row of the second column is 14+4=18, and the number in the third row of the second column is 18+4=22.
The number in the second row of the third column is 22+4=26.
Since the numbers in the third column form an arithmetic sequence with a common difference of $-14$, the number in the second row of the third column is $26 + (-14) = 12$.
The number in the first row of the third column is $12 + 14 = 26.$
Since the numbers in the first column form an arithmetic sequence with common difference $26-14=12$, the number in the second row of the first column is $14+12=26$.
Final Answer
